text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Tuesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
LIETUVOS RYTAS

- Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas told the newspaper he would like to see continuity of foreign and domestic politicy after the shift of parliament to the right after the first round of elections and thinks the formation of new government will be "full of responsibility and a complicated task".

- The final results of parliamentary elections have not been released but the Homeland Union have taken a sure lead and it is clear already that the Lithuanian Democratic Labour Party has lost its status as ruling party.
- Short-term government bond yields reached a record low average, less than nine precent, at auction on Monday.
- The unemployment rate fell by 2.7 percent in Lithuania and there were 112,500 jobless on October 1.
- The securities commission registered on Friday the eight million litas share emission by Siauliu Bank. The share capital will be boosted to 20.021 million litas.
- The World Bank approved an $80 million credit to Lithuania which will help to carry on economic reforms in the country.

- Vytautas Landsbergis was the only one to win in the first round of parliament elections in the majority vote single list constituencies. Other candidates will have to run off in the second round scheduled for November 10.
RESPUBLIKA

- The shareholders of leading bank Vilnius Bank decided to change the nominal amount and number of its shares to make trading on the stock exchange easier and simplify accounting. The majority of its shares will be turned into ordinary shares with a 50 litas nominal price.
- Preliminary data showed that the activity of the electorate in the four south east constituencies dominated by Poles was lower than 40 percent, meaning new elections should be held there.
- The Homeland Union are now sure of 32 seats in parliament and have a good chances of increasing this number in the second round of elections.

- Vytautas Landsbergis intends to continue the foreign policy of the former Supreme Council he was heading before 1992 and ex-prime minister Gediminas Vagnorius, likely to resume this post, would like to unpeg the litas currency from the dollar as soon as possible.
LIETUVOS AIDAS
- The right-wing thinks the second round vote on November 10 will be decisive.
VERSLO ZINIOS

- Although the Homeland Union sees Gediminas Vagnorius as new prime minister, the strategists of the former ruling Lithuanian Democratic Labour Party decided long before the elections that the decisive decisions choice on a new cabinet should be taken by President Algirdas Brazauskas.
- Timber industry, five percent of industrial output, shows signs of recovery. Experts think bigger state support is necessary to modernise production lines.
-- Riga Newsroom +371 7 22 66 93
